David, the dichotomy you reference between profit-making and social good is a recent phenomenon. It is only since the mid-1980's, and the watershed influence of Milton Friedman and Ronald Reagan, that America has embraced the idea that business should devote itself simply and solely to profit-making. Previously, the consensus view was that business needed to balance its drive to make a profit with a recognition of its social responsibilities. As a result, companies rarely relocated just because profit might be enlarged elsewhere, nor did they even think about outsourcing jobs to India or elsewhere. Instead, they operated under the belief that they had certain compelling moral obligations including, first and foremost, to (try hard to) provide stable, lasting employment to their workers and communities.

That sounds rather quaint today. Yet the decades during which that conception of business prevailed marked the period during which America became the world's dominant economic power. In other words, that version of capitalism - one in which businesses pursued both profit and (certain) social objectives as well - worked quite successfully. Most of our business forbears would be quite surprised, therefore, to hear today's apologists argue that a commitment to social responsibility has no place in business. To a degree, at least, today's social entrepreneurs are simply re-embracing a conception of capitalism that long held sway.

A healthy society has hundreds and hundreds of small businesses in varying stages of growth. Some fail, some don't . If the regulatory climate favors small business, some will succeed spectacularly. Many jobs are created, employment is good, Money is produced and recycled within the communities. If microcredit can help this climate, great!

An unhealthy society has a few huge mindless and ethic free parasitic giants sucking out all the money (and jobs) from the communities- money that could be recycled over and over within the communities and taxes that could be paid ( if regulations enforced this) disappear into some foregin bank, never to be seen again. It is pretty clear to me which is preferable.

And don't naively imagine for a moment that just because there may be an "increasingly visible salience of scientific ideas" means the average NYT reader actually understands any of those ideas any better than in Snow’s day.

Remember that Snow was not just a “scientist” - he was much more than that. He was a physicist.

Unfortunately, even quite competent mathematicians often have difficulty with physics because they don’t understand the key role in physics of the physical units. Much of physics concerns itself with apparently mundane, nitpicking but critically important details such as the definition and measurement of physical quantities.

Mathematicians generally don’t concern themselves with physical quantity (in the case of a scalar quantity, the product of a number and a physical unit) - only with number – and just don’t get it why physicists are so bothered about the rigorous definition of units of measurement when it comes to building models of the universe.

If even many mathematicians don’t understand the fuss about the need for such intellectual rigour (pedantry in the eyes of many) in the practise of physics, no wonder then that most NYT readers didn’t have a clue about physics in Snow’s day and they still haven't.

My friend and my wife at Millennium Suites Akbiyik between 24nd-28th October 2010. I must admit that we spent a lot of our time looking at several hotels within Istanbul, but finally settled on this one for overall value for money and location - and that is exactly what we got and more!

The hotel is located in a local part of the Sultanahmet district, and all famous tourist attractions are within 5-10 minutes walk away. Amenities and towels are supplied, so no need to lug extra stuff with you!

Staff were very nice and friendly, especially front desk Erhan (?) and the two young men we saw every day before setting out. They helped us with almost everything such as suggesting places to visit, restaurants, directions, and transport etc.

Breakfast was also very nice, in fact, my friend looked forward to having breakfast at Art City every morning!

If I had to fault the hotel then it would be that the street is noisy and if you leave the windows open you are bound to hear the locals talking, and loudly! As we were staying for a long weekend, the other guests in the hotel also seemed a little 'merrier' than preferred but I'd say that's the effects of alcohol more than anything!

I would also recommend booking a transfer of some sort to get you to the hotel because it isn't that easy to find for first timers! It's not on a main road and to get to it without a map or knowledge of street names etc would be a nightmare! The hotel provides a complimentary airport shuttle service but this is only free for those who booked through their website.

We thoroughly enjoyed our stay in Istanbul and I feel thatMillennium Suites contributed to the wonderful experience, so thank you! And yes, I would definitely recommend this hotel to people.

Oh, and one more thing, there are lots of stairs and hills in Istanbul, and though Millennium Suites isn't located on one (it's sort of in the middle?), you will come probably come across a hill or two on your strolls, so be warned! Bring good walking shoes!
http://www.themillenniumsuites.com

I offer my own experience as testimony to this new finding. My mother-in-law and a very close friend developed Alzheimer’s and difficulty managing money was, in retrospect, an early indication that a problem was brewing. Both had difficulty managing their checkbooks and my friend early on could not add a column of figures.

Well maybe its time that the financial advisors relearn fiduciary responsibility instead of just boosting commissions? Capacity does not have to be breached for any fiduciary to know that they should act in the best interests of their client, even if that means that they might lose the client. I hope we have not lost sight of the fact that this is the basic reason one seeks a trusted financial advisor in the first place? Attorneys are a whole 'nother story however...

I had an aging aunt who I convinced to engage an accountant; however, he was cowed by an aggressive broker she knew through church and an attorney who never cooperated with anyone but her. It's a terrible situation for most aging people who have money, not just those who may suffer early sypmtoms of a debilitating disease such as Alzheimer's.

I've never understood what money is.  Wampum, gold, paper money.  All man made values.  Buy, sell, trade it till the moon turns blue.  None of it has any real value.  It's less then cheese but it has us all running around the maze.  I can still remember my name and address too.

With so many people in the position of having "money woes" this article will no doubt instill the idea in some of them that perhaps their condition is not really financial but MEDICAL.  Here's how it might sound: "Hi dear, I may not really have a problem making the house payment next month; in fact, I may not even have a financial problem at all; it may only be an early sign of dementia!  Is this good news or not?"  Can this be helpful?

This is a true statement.  I noticed my mom's problems due to a hospital visit which she had because she was stressed about money.  She didn't know what was going on (turns out scammers were draining her life savings, slowly at first but by the time she went in the hospital, hundreds were going every month).  There will be a cure for this, one day.  Till then, watch for the signs.

There are many forms of dementia besides Alzheimer's. My father had kidney failure and suffered from lack of haemoglobin; my mother had TIAs and could not remember me at all. Neither had Alzheimer's, but both suffered from dementia.

My father, realising that he was no longer competent, voluntarily turned control of all his money over to a trust with my sister and a bank as trustees, so no one outside our family could get it.
This is like wolves tending sheeps.

What is the point of living with a brain so ravaged that even balancing a checkbook becomes an impossible task? We are our memories, our minds; when those go we are nothing more than lumps of flesh running on autopilot. This kind of treading-water death in life is painful and pointless. I am now in my 60's and have never understood why people cling so to live. Everything ends, everything dies; far better to go out on your own terms with what little dignity remains to you.

Assuming knowlege of the six stages of Alzheimer's, you need to be aware of "how and when key decision-making events occur and what response is made," e.g., a plea for assistance in deciding or firm denial of any problem and postponement of the entire matter. Whether a post-surgery decision, responding to a forclosure notice, or a telephone request for personal checking account information from strangers, the competent friend or relative of the Alzheimer's-afflicted person has to be aware of such possible events and take the initiative. On the one hand, an existing durable power of attorney, created without a sacrifice of a person's pride, may already be in place and require, when needed, a doctor's examination of the patient, tests and a medical certification for someone to assume the responsibility of attorney-in-fact. On the other hand, if there is no durable power of attorney, living trust, or conservatorship in place, the patient is "totally at risk" to declining cognitive capacity and critical decision-making. Legal issues of competency coupled with "dispute time" will simply compound and delay the prudent exercise of financial and health care judgments required, particularly when the patient has no immediate relative who is both responsible and committed to be involved right through the end. No investment broker or bank manager will take the knowledgeable initiave to "protect" the investor or bank customer, as long as the management fee or money reinbursement are guaranteed to them. In my own final analysis, personal trust in a relative or friend and foresight in planning for the eventual or inevitable are effective risk mitigators for all concerned.

The stories of once-astute people losing their life savings as a result of mental incompetence are heartbreaking, and will become more common, I predict, as the percentage of persons receiving income from defined-benefit (read traditional) pension plans decreases. A guaranteed supplemental income for life turns out to be a good thing, after all, but the majority of employers have nevertheless adopted the 'you're on your own, aside from Social Security, which, by the way, we favor reducing and/or privatizing' approach. Individual annuities can be bought, but many employees are unable to put aside enough defined contribution plan savings to fund an adequate retirement income stream.

Protecting individuals of any mental capacity earlier in their careers, by insisting that businesses, including sole proprietorships, provide adequate retirement plans, would be infinitely preferable to, and, indeed, even eliminate the need for, most interference in the personal business of elderly citizens who may or may not be competent to manage their own affairs, and the attendant hazard of abuse by over-zealous others.
